reviewText:
I wanted to love this game. I really did.

It's with quite a heavy heart do I give this game a dreaded thumbs down, but there's honestly one rather large reason why, and  it can be summed up a simple sentence:

The game has no weight.

Firstly, let me get it out of the way that the 30fps nonsense and the co-op controversy does NOT bother me much. Go read other reviews to find out more about it. It definitely affects the choices of other players and other gamers, but I just happen to be one who doesn't mind 30fps nor have any friends, so the issue didn't really factor in! If it does or doesn't with you, that's also something to take note of, and something that other people can cover better than I.

But getting to the meat of it, weight (or the lack thereof) is something that can be applied to a lot of things in this game. Let's go through the nibblets one by one.

Gameplay:
Unlike every other one of Platinum's games, the fighting in this game feels hollow and lifeless. I'm not sure what it is, but there is this lack of a satisfying THUNK with every hit, almost as if things aren't even really connecting. Each slash and attack doesn't register with your senses, and were it not for individual life bars and body flashing, it'd be hard to tell that you did any damage at all. This is compared to other games in their history such as Bayonetta or Wonderful 101 or even Transformers where each punch, each special power and each defense carries a lot of, well, punch. I'm not entirely sure what's missing, but something is.

Story:
The story is also kinda weightless in the sense that there's really a lack of a single thread tying anything together. The first few stages (1 - 6) can be played in any order, which means that as far as a cohesive story matters, it's simply a case of 'fight here until the boss shows up and then fight him' in terms of the micro-story, and nothing more than 'the Foot is up to no good' as an over-arcing plot. Now, while this is not necessarily the worst thing, and there ARE a lot of games which are very good that don't rely at all on plot, it's just something that would have worked better in favour of this game specifically, since the game tries to pretend that it has one. Since the game isn't linear, they can't really write good intrigue into each chapter without it just being repetitious. So why bother? The work could have gone into making each chapter more self-contained, and have the game be about missions out there in the wild instead.

Stage Mechanics:
Stages sort of occur as follows:
- Go to area
- Do random stuff in area until boss is triggered
- Do boss
- Party tiems winrar
Now, the issue I have with this is the randomness of the 'random stuff'. The game is kinda unashamed at admitting that nothing really matters or has anything to do with the actual boss fight or plot of the stage itself, so the weightlessness comes in in this point with how redundant anything is. For example, in Rocksteady's stage, the 4 random 'quests' I had to do was carry 8 billion bars of gold across a platform with Sudden Death Lasers hindering me, deactivating 5 bombs in an area, and checking computers to find out where the Foot Clan was not once but twice in two seperate events. None of these have anything really to do with the actual story. Checking computers, alright. Sure. But the randomness of it (since the computers literally just spawn into the ground rather than being in intelligent locations) makes it feel like a slap-dash job with no real forethought. Also, carrying gold? The delivery point was literally just across the platform, and the only reason why it's difficult is because lasers suddenly come out from NOWHERE to hinder you just for that one sequence, and then you leave the gold on the floor at the other end and it's okay, I guess. Why is there gold being stolen in the subway, even?
While I admit the randomness actually does give a really fun feel of a 'living' world, it was just not implemented on any meaningful scale to me, and I found myself distracted by it more than having fun.
Besides, the big joke is, once I finally HAD used the computers to 'pinpoint' the location of the Foot activity, it just turned off a laser door that was the first thing I saw in the entire stage and said to myself 'there's something behind there'. The game is far too dumb for itself, and Platinum has known to be a lot smarter. Something got into the water, and it must have been old pizza.

Voice Acting:
Is terrible. Is hollow. None of them sound like they mean what they say. There is a line when one of the turtles dies that is horrendously delivered. It is a stutter where each single syllable is prounounced as if it were its own word. This is weightless because you don't feel like the actors mean it. There's no oomph. There's no flair, and no style. It's terrible.

Visual Style:
Actually this one's pretty freaking nice. I have no problems with it whatsoever.

Control:
Outside of the fact that hits don't feel like they hurt, the game controls pretty good, really! So again, I have nothing to say, and this is a big plus in my book. Oh yeah, they run really slow, though. Doesn't feel like they're moving fast at all.

Fighting Mechanics:
This one's weird. This one is a negative in my book, but not because of lack of trying. I like the idea of using all four turtles. What I DON'T like is how complicated it is to use them. Each has their own inventory and load out, which is cool. Each has their own fighting style, and way of doing things, which is ALSO cool. ALL FOUR SWARM YOUR SCREEN LIKE IDIOTS, which is not cool. Quite a lot of the time, I find myself not really having to do much since my cool bros do everything for me. Setting the AI to just hang around turns them into bricks, in a way that they don't really do anything at all. The game, unfortunately, is balanced for the swarm, since there are infinitely-spawning enemies who try to swarm you back, and certain enemies and bosses have unfairly huge life bars to make up for it. The game wasn't built around the idea of you being a turtle fighting. It was centered around the idea of you playing a team, AS a team (sorta wonderful 101 style) but it didn't really work out. Individual action is confused with action of the group, and in places where it should be handled as a group, it doesn't, such as life gain. You get one new 'pip' of life for every 500 points of score you earn while in a level (which resets to default every time you start a new level), but it only applies to the turtle you're controlling at the time. So if you favour one, he gets a load more life and others trail behind. Yet, when you fight by yourself, you EASILY get swarmed by certain types of units, such as those chain-ninjas that basically spam and lock you up. A lot of in-game actions take a heck of a long time to complete too, upwards of 20 seconds by my estimate, and your AI buddies need to keep enemies at bay.

But at the same time, you can switch between any of the turtles on the fly, which don't share life gain, but DO share item usage (I think? Maybe not even then!), and... it's kinda confusing if the game is supposed to be a character action game or a characters actions games with too many plurals.

Final thoughts:
I bought this game because I like TMNT games, and Platinum is cool. However, it doesn't mean they can't sometimes make mistakes. Everyone has to, once in a while, and sometimes our favourite franchises are sorely mishandled. I've already refunded this game to purchase Transformers Devastation again on this computer because it's far, far better. I appreciate Platinum for trying, but if there's anything I can say about this game, it's the shiniest movie tie-in game that I actually know of (since the TMNT movie is coming out soon, eh!)

Well, they tried. And so did I. And so should you, if you like TMNT. But don't expect anything more than just a polished pile of steaming hope.

reviewText:
tl;dr: you are gonna be disappointed if you expect this one to be one of those Platinum quality action titles. The elements adapted from the original are fine, but the core mechanics feel rushed and unpolished.

Speaking of a disappointment...errrrr
I love Platinum Games, I love TMNT, I tried to love this one, but I just can't.

I love Bayonetta. Bayonetta is the type of game that looks totally chaotic during every single battle, but everything are still managable and under the players' control, and all the rewards gained from skilled play go right to the players themselves. That's the reason why traditional action games are so addictive for the players who are willing to spend some extra time to dig into the game: we, as players, are achiving everything, and it feels like it.

In the case of TMNT:MiM, everything still looks chaotic but...not really under my control. When my AI allies just run right into the crowds of enemies, I hardly stand a chance to pull of even a single complete set of combo without missing one or two slashes, then everything ends when you haven't even figured out what is going on on the screen. While the dodge system is still a thing this time around, the reward couldn't justify the precision demanded to pull it off. Enemy's attack indicators(both visual and sound) are inconsistent and difficult to read especially in the middle of a chaotic battle, and the camera angle can even make it worse in some indoor sequences.

Something new for Platinum action games are implemented in this game for sure, like the open world design, but the idea overall is poorly executed and the set pieces just simply doesn't work with each other. I appreciate the art direction they have taken, but the environment of the levels doesn't have a lot of variety by each one of themselves, and they can feel bland and samey over time easily since you often have to spend some time explore around these levels. The quests are usually series of fetch quests, which I wouldn't even bother to talk about.

This game is far away from those actually demanding traditional action game titles, so 30fps is totally playable. However, with this level of graphical technologies implemented, this level of performance just couldn't be justified, despite the fact that the team mentioned that it would be targeting 60fps on all platforms. The fps is still capped even you turn off v-sync is straight up stupid.

What bugs me the most is the prerendered cutscenes. They look no better than the actual gameplay from a technical perspective which means they can totally be replaced by real-time rendering, and the cutscenes themselves have constant noticeable frame dips. Such level of unpolishedness just couldn't justify its price tag.

But there are still some upsides: the writing is still what you can expect from TMNT, the characters are there, and the facial expressions of the turtles during the cutscenes are really impressive.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I played and beat this game offline, as I usually play all my Steam games offline. I played online just so I could write a review about it, because I really enjoyed it.

At first, I was baffled at how this game could receive such mixed reviews, but the more I thought about it, the more it makes sense. That's not to say I think it's a bad game, I personally think it's great, but I also think it depends on a player's personal preference to see whether or not they'd enjoy it.

The simple beauty in Mutants in Manhattan is that it's little else than what it claims to be; a love letter to die hard TMNT fans. That being said, it's probably going to be much more enjoyable to that kind of audience rather than to just any gamer who could be more or less indifferent to the turtles.

Pros:

+ Very enjoyable to those who liked the great old SNES TMNT games like Turtles in Time and Tournament Fighters
+ Fun, challenging gameplay and boss fights
+ Sandbox-esque areas for each level with randomly generated mission assortments that increase replay value
+ Introduces fun elements previously unseen in past Turtles games
+ Some pretty nice music in a good number of parts in the game
+ Pick and customize whichever turtle you like at practically all times
+ Many things that will please Turtles fans of any kind, especially rewarding for longtime/devoted ones

Cons:

- Not for those who place exaggerated importance in graphics (I'd recommend using CPUCores if it really bothers you that much)
- No local multiplayer
- There's so much pizza in the game you'll go insane with hunger and place an order for delivery that'll hit your wallet harder than a Steam summer sale

In summary, Mutants in Manhattan is, ironically, a lot like a distinct type of pizza; some people love it, some people hate it, and everyone has a different opinion about it.

My recommendation in the end is this;

If you're a gamer looking for a fun time, but aren't necessarily crazy about Turtles, carefully consider it, check out gameplay videos and maybe see if one of your friends has it and will let you check it out.

If you're a TMNT fan, it's a strongly encouraged buy; you could always just refund it if you end up not liking it.

Either way, if nothing else, it's a much better game than the only other TMNT experience currently on Steam (Out of the Shadows).

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan is the newest action game by PlatinumGames. Through the years PlatinumGames has made a lot of these 3D beat-em ups. Most of their games are very similar to one another and Mutants In Manhattan is really no different... Sort of. The one thing I can never figure out is how they go from making Bayonetta to making something like Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan. It isn't just the style or IP in question it is the quality.  Last year we had Transformers Devastation and it was a pretty decent game. The action was fun and kind of flowed together. This year however we have Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan and things are so much they same... that they aren't... Let me explain.



With every Platinum Games, game you have the heavy action game with combos, dodging, jumping, parrying, blocking, and consumables.  EVERY SINGLE game by Platinum is like that. They all also have some sort of character progression be it skills, new abilities, or items. None of that changes in Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan. However the problem is the combat doesn't really flow all that well together, and it isn't nearly as fun to watch.  In Transformers Devastation you have giant robots using big weapons and yet somehow they manage to feel faster, and move better than the NINJA Turtles do. Yes, Turtles, but... Ninjas ? Eh, maybe I should focus on the turtle part, but anyone who has ever watched TMNT knows that they are more Ninja than turtle... Well that and pizza loving maniacs.



On the very first mission it is a semi open world level where you can move around the map, fight foot ninja's and explore. There are a few collectibles to grab but ultimately your using your T'Glass to find the mission targets and defeat them to trigger the Boss Encounter. The first boss being Bebop. Now I was playing on Normal and I am pretty use to Platinum Games so I am no slouch when it comes to combat. Yet Bebop has 7 bars of health! SEVEN! It takes freaking forever to beat him. I'm not really dying. It isn't difficult. It is just bland. After about three health bars it just gets old.



Then you realize right from the start you can skip around missions in any order. Right from the very beginning. So when I was playing with twitch partner ReclaimJoey we went from Bebop to Shredder. From the first boss to the last one. To get to shredder we did this 15 minute elevator ride where we fought the same 3 or 4 mobs then finally got to the tower to fight Shredder himself. He was easier than Bebop was.  Seemingly that you don't need any real progression to fight any boss. Ultimately making the entire progression system rather pointless. We would have beaten Shredder to if not for having lost connection while playing. Then the kicker there is when I got disconnected it sent him to a continue screen without warning and it happened so fast he ended up pushing do not continue or cancel. Thus if we wanted to fight Shredder again we would have to do that very boring 15 minute elevator ride all over again.



The music for the game got so extremely repetitive I would rather have jabbed screwdrivers into my hear lobes than having to listen to the music again. Now the dialogue isn't to bad, and honestly might be the best part of the game. They managed to capture the essence of every Turtle and villain very well in the game. It very much reminded me of the ORIGINAL TMNT cartoon back when i was a kid.



The game as I mentioned does have online co-op. I did the first mission with Bebop two or three times and never really had any issue. However once I tried playing with friends then the connection issues began. Which I mean it worked about 70% of the time which is more than I can say for the last TMNT game that came to steam. Then finally we have something a lot of gamers hate. They decided lets lock the games frame rate to 30 fps. WHY?! I mean sure It doesn't bother me all that much because for several years my hardware didn't let me play games for more than 30 fps anyway. However with the new technology there is no reason to do that so I would love to hear some sort of explanation on why devs still do this.



I was very excited for Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan because it brought me some nostalgia from when I was a child. I was a huge TMNT fan. I had the van they drove, all the action figures and play sets. My friends and I would set up this elaborate play sessions. It was amazing. The cartoon was amazing, however the game... just let down after let down. I have never really felt so disappointed with a video game until I played Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan. I think, no I KNOW Platinum could have done better. Just look at Bayonetta 2.  Hell even The Legend of Korra was a good game. Heads and tails better than Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan, and Korra was like 15$ at launch. So there is no way in hell can I recommend Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles - Mutants in Manhattan to anyone at the price of 39.99. This is a 15$ game at best and even then I am not to sure.

I've never played a worse action game by Platinum.

I'll gloss over the awful PC port (it's Platinum, after all), and I'll even look past the framerate issues (which I probably shouldn't, but others have touched on them) and get right to the heart of it:

As a fan of the Ninja Turtles series since I was only a kid, I heard about Platinum making a game based on the series I thought it was a match made in heaven. And after I completed the game, this is what I felt afterwards:

Conflicted.

I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with this game. Why? Here's why:

As a guy that loves to cause chaos in certain games or be in the centre of chaos, this is way too much. Too much goes on and it is hard to keep track of it all.

The controls on this are wierd. Like with every hit with a nunchuck, bo-staff, sai blades and katanas, I don't feel the impact of them. The guard button doesn't do this much justice as it also serves as a dodge and counter. But running, grinding and gliding feel decent plus the boss battles are the most enjoyable you'll be able to get out of this game.

The voice acting makes me feel like I'm watching some type of spin on the series, which is nice. Although, hearing the turtles thank each other and say their one-liners (which are very few) gets tiring as hell.

I haven't tried the multiplayer since I was slightly intimidated by it thinking that I would jump into a very hard game, but I would have liked to try this with friends.

The characters look great with the cell-shaded style that Transformers Devastation had but the levels aren't that interesting. You got your typical city, sewer and krang alien hidey-hole levels to go through. There's also these 'side-quests' you have to do to reach the boss of each stage and they range from fighting a group of enemies, finding a hideout, defusing bombs and downloading intel, which is fine and all if it wasn't for the fact that there is so much of them.



Overall, I give this a 7/10. It's alright as a beat-em up and a Platinum game. I would recommend waiting until a price drop on this (or if you have a console) buy a pre-owned copy of the game. But if you want a pure Platinumgames experience, buy either Bayonetta, Anarchy Reigns, MGR Revengeance or even Transformers Devastation. I might throw Legend of Korra in there if you crave for more.

All in all Mutants In Manhattan is a great little game if you take it for what it is. If you're a fan of old school beat 'em ups you can't really go wrong, consider it is as a modern version of Turtle's In Time and you'll definitely have a blast with it.

reviewText:
I came into this game hoping to like it more however that wasn't to be.
Now I'm not saying this game is bad.  It's alright but very flawed.

The graphics are alright.  It's the same cell shaded look that was very pervasive in Transformers: Devastation and it lent itself pretty well to the action and allowed for very easy identification of what was out of bounds.

The turtles designs were somewhat disorienting at first with them looking more anime than I'm used to especially since it doesn't really look like the nickelodeon version but rather the current comic versions of the turtles.  As with the last PC ninja  turtle brawler April herself is an adult this time around.  Krangs' robot body in this game kinda lacks the oomph that the 80's Krang had with it's doofy robot body.  In fact in this game it kinda look generic.  Now he does have a second one that looks way cooler but that's endgame.

The partner A.I. is probably some of the best I have come across in this kind of game.  The other turtles when not being controlled by another player can handle themselves pretty well and need little saving from the player.  They will do things like use whatever super abilities that you have given them consitently along with combo with each other when possible.  They will also prioritize reviving fallen teammates so if one goes down, one of the other remaining turtles will break off from the battle and attempt to revive them.  I think they even use items that they have picked up along the way at appropriate times too such as healing items and mobile turrets.

The controls aren't bad at all and seem to be a slightlier simple version of what you had in Transformers.  That being said unlike that game you can't change the primary weapons that each turtle has but instead you can equip them with a variety of different super abilities.  A neat thing about this is that the super abilities can be leveled up and when they are it isn't leveled up only for the character that upgraded it but leveled up for whoever has it equipped.  So if leo and don have a level 1 ability and leo upgrades it to two then it will also be level two for don.

As far as the soundtrack goes.  Well it's kinda bland in a lot of places.  It feels generic and not really distinctive especially in certain stages such as the subway.

I guess it's time to get into the some of the negatives of this game.
Let's start thing off with the campaign mission or co-op:
In single player mode you can only start with the first stage and the others unlock as you progress through the game.  Now if you want to go back to an earlier stage you can but the level select shows all the stages in the game whether you unlocked them or not so now you have high chance of spoiling yourself on what's to come even if you don't want to.

In co-op it's even worse since all stages are unlocked from the get go and everytime you do complete a stage you have to use the level select to select the next stage since it always reverts to the first stage for some reason.  But the problem here is that it's entirely possible to just jump right to the final battle without even doing a single stage just after you bought the game.

Another bad point is that you can't even experience the games story in it's entirety in co-op mode.  The story related cutscenes that do show up in co-op mode are the ones that are in the stages themselves.  Heck once you beat the last boss you don't even get any resolution to the game.  Once the last stage related cutscene plays you get dumped back into the lobby.  No ending custscene no credits just the lobby.  So if you want to play the game for it's story and actually see it fully along with the games credits then the only way to do that is through story mode which is the single player campaign.

The game does have different difficulty settings with very hard being locked out unless you beat the game on hard.  However that can be bypassed by simply loading in multiplayer because along with every stage being unlocked from the start you get access to all the dificulties too.  Even Very Hard which is only locked out in single player.  So if you don't really care about non-level cutscenes and such and just want to play the game on Very Hard without doing it on Hard first then you can load in multiplayer start the game with just yourself and boom now you can.

The levels feel way shorter than they really are but they can also feel bland especially the sewer levels where at one point I forgot I was in a future sewer level because it looked exactly like the first sewer level and even had the same overall objective.

There are secret boss fight in the game but to get to those you just have to wail on the stage boss quick enough for the secret boss to show up.  Which was kind of disappointing I was hoping that it was an exploration thing that required you to explore the level in order to find them.  The secret bosses themselves aren't really that secret.  What they are is just the boss of the next stage coming in to help the regular boss.  You are not going to be fighting optional bosses.

As for the fights themselves. Depending on difficulty every boss will have the same amount of health bars.  For instance on my playthrough they all had seven.  If you managed to trigger the secret boss to show the secret boss had two and they make the fight exponentially tougher.  Overall though if done right you could end up in a fight having to deplete a total of nine healthbars to finish the grueling battle.  They all feel very samey until the last two.

All said this game could have been better that what we got.  I'll give that at least it's multiplayer works which is more than I can say about out of the shadows and playing with friends is fun and makes the game easier but then you would be missing story elements and the actual end of the game.

Overall as I stated earlier it's a decent but flawed game with Transformers: Devastation being the better game.
I hope this review helped you and would reccomend just getting the game when it goes on sale if you want to give it a try.

I honestly have fun with it. I'm use to long fights from some past games, but I do see why people would think them a tad bit long in comparason to fights of turtle games past. The difficulty curve can swing a bit wide at times from rather high, to rather low but does reward some decent timing and pattern learning like the ye old boss fights past.

There's special abilities to swap between your turtles, join in team attacks which is nice to see come back again to co op gaming, charms to give you various abilities like explosive throwing stars, and a bunch of items you can collect the usual gem type items to buy from Splinter in game by diving down obviously marked manholes along the way.

Combat feels a bit loose, but tight enough that you can time some of those counters and jump on a bosses back. Stealth kills could've been a bit more fancy once in a while, but you get in and get the job done when they're not ready for you. When the fight is on, different patterns of light and heavy are the name of the game classic walk around beat em up style for a chunk of it and each turtle has his own style that make each their own in combat. And you are very much still a threat at range with throwing stars and those above spoken about special moves, four that have cool down times, and can be jumped in on by a friend to up the power for an all the more flashy move are very much present and welcome.

Art is nice, I dig the soundtrack, particularly some of the metal tunes durring boss fights, dialog feels right, the venture though not always the best of level design still has some good ones, certainly feeling at home for the turtles with the variety of the streets with grindable railings, roof tops above, even higher sky scrapers, down in the sewers where you can water slide with the current in many of them and swing off of posts, so on and so forth. Art works out for this game plenty better than the last one and of coarse there is what I felt Platinum's Transformer game needed.

Co op with your friends.

Too me that's a high selling point and though not all of you out there can work an arcade like mine, or even find one near by, but I do believe in the meeting new people and bonding with friends as you get together and whip some baddies kind of experience. There should be more of it again and though it's not absolutly gone from gaming, I feel it should be all the more pressed. This game I feel does that more than just a little reasonably well. I saw a couple bugs on the day one release, but it doesn't feel like a regular thing and much of it feels patched up for the most part. Even when they were present, they were more comical for the moment than forever game breaking.

Honestly one player, you can do it, but we know what most came here for other than the turtles brand. The best of the turtles has always been with a friend when it comes to the games, and if they made this one one player, it would've been a crying shame. I'm still really scratching my head about Transformers and their decesion to keep it one player. I mean a huge chunk of the dialog is about the bots communicating together and even doing combat shoulder to shoulder. Why in the HELL would I not be able to bring my friends in on that?!

Still think Transformers should be upgraded for co op. The kind of game it is just kinda begs for it.

Back on the turtles though, it's not the greatest ever made, but it's a posative entry. Combat feel wierd? So does anything you play for the first time, and the hold R or whatever button you assign to do a cool lil shell spin as a block that can be timmed for a last minute rewarding block, released at just the right time for a chance to grab on the enemy, or even not sure what the timing will be so spinning to buffer into or out of a bad situation with a ballancing mechanic that will dizzy you if you run out.... I think it works just fine and makes sense!

Again it's not the greatest ever made, but other than perhaps the fact by cranking some of the visuals up with filters it can actually make the experience look worse, I don't have much to complain about here. It works, the turtles have varried moves but not severely lacking to be well off on their own, things still reward for sticking together, team move moves are nice and bond building, I can understand some gripes but I can't see voting it down. At least not on my behalf, and so I shant. It may not be something you play through over and over, but some indeed might as there is, as said, things to collect and try out. It's just a good solid game that released at a lower price because I feel Platnimum games made tittles put in a good fair effort and ask for a pretty fair price for it.

In short, it's a fun time, and I'm always a supporter of a game that likes to put people together for a fun romp and builds from there, and that's what this is. A fun romp with friends. It's enough to keep you at least through one run. If it's tag is too much, get it on sale. I feel it's not only worth it if you score it all the lower, it's either way just one tittle I believes desrves not to be over looked. I've seen much much worse, and at the end of the day I had real fun with it, and it let me do that with others to get my social time in along with my baddies beatings, and did it without breaking bugs to remain fun, it's done it's job.

Can't make everyone happy, but not everyone is so very open minded either.

As you can see, I've put in 6+ hours into the game.

First, if you're expecting Metal Gear Rising/Bayonetta, the game is definitely not that.  The closest Platinum game I can compare this to is Wonderful 101/Legend of Korra, since switching between each turtle is like switching styles/bending.  You just happen to have everyone fighting together at the same time.

Is the game combo heavy?  Not really. Each turtle has a different moveset, but knowing when to dodge and backattack helps more than doing long combo streams.  You'll mainly be switching between turtles to setup jiutsu (HEALING CIRCLE, PIZZA PARTY, COMBO ATTACK, and attack specific to each Turtle is my usual Load out).

The biggest advice I can give is upgrade your Jiutsus and Talismans.  Don't buy every Jiutsu, just try to max out the ones you use the most, then experiment with other techniques.

Hard difficulty adds the random chance of double boss encounters.  Example being Rocksteady jumping into the fight with Bebop once you reach a certain point into Bebops health.

I notice a lot of negative reviews.  I was about to do the same, but once you level up a bit the game opens up.  The enemies become more varied and can take a full combo, and using Double co-op Jitsus can be pretty fun (Michaelangelo's dance special freezes all enemies into disco poses for one hit kills).

The game isn't perfect, but its still not the worst Turtle game I've played (which would be the TURTLES IN TIME 2.5D Remake).

reviewText:
Better than the general consensus seems to indicate and a must buy if you're a Turtles fan. That said, I'd wait for a sale.

As is clear by the mixed reviews, this isn't a perfect game. Level design leaves something to be desired and the occasional bug creeps in. Those looking for super tight combat will be disappointed because the fights are frenetic with lots of enemies on screen at once which makes skillful play difficult at times. All of that aside though, there are also things to love and a lot of fun to be had as long as you temper your expectations.

The core single player game involves rotating between the 4 turtles and utilizing their cooldown timer special ninjutsu moves in strategic and complimentary ways. If you approach this is a straight up action game and try to stay with one turtle all off the time, you'll find that it is extremely difficult and frustrating.

On the topic of the special moves, you acquire more throughout the game and they are all upgradeable. Getting familiar with the upgrade system is essential to maximize fun and over time your turtles get more and more awesome as their skill sets get more spectacular.

As far as the common complaints you read about the 30 FPS and the short campaign... the game looks great and oozes style, and the 9 stages in the game are meant to be played more than once. There's a bit of a grind element as you earn Battle Points to buy more ninjutsu and upgrade existing ones. I've played some of the stages at least a half dozen times now to earn more BP and also find the collectible comic book covers.

About the collectible covers, they are the Kevin Eastman drawn cover variants (for his fan club subscribers) of the current IDW comic and issues 1-50 are represented.

The game has flaws but this is honestly the best Turtles game in years. Don't be scared off by the negative reviews.

reviewText:
This game is actually surprisingly not bad. With all the review bombing you'd expect less, but it seems most of the people giving this game bad reviews are whiny babies that either suck at games, aren't putting any effort in to playing it, or have that stupid 60FPS master race taboo. There is nothing wrong with a 30FPS game. Get over it.

Talking more about the game, there's some things I'd like to touch on.

Combat - It's Platinum Games. It's a beat em up. Same as pretty much all their games are. You go in to a mission, you beat stuff up. If you expect more than that, you're in the wrong genre. Easy & Normal is a faceroll, if you want excitement out of this game, Hard mode at least, or in the best scenario, get a couple friends and play Very Hard. You don't need a whole team, even one or two buddies is enough if you play smart. You get specials and such you can blast enemies with, and the turtles have some pretty incredible synergies. i.e - Raphaels Stealth + Leos Time Stop, or Mikeys Combo Attack + any AoE can wipe whole groups pretty well.

Dodging / Parrying / Grappling - There's so many ways to avoid damage for a reason, if you play the game on a real difficulty setting, you actually have to use these. Sometimes getting tagged means instant death if you're not wearing a Willpower charm, so if you want to tackle Hard / Very Hard, you have to learn how to stay alive. You can't just faceroll. You have to dodge, counter, and sometimes just plain run away to win a fight. You know, like a Ninja. Go figure.

The AI - I heard a lot of people complaining about the AI, about them doing their jobs fighting and such, and I have to say. What? I've beaten Hard mode alone, and the AI fight perfectly fine. They deal damage, they're pretty good at staying alive, the only thing they lack in is revival speed, but you can jack them out with Competitive Eater charms and then that aspect is null. The AI aren't meant to carry you. You have to learn to play the game yourself, habibi.

Content - This is the only thing kinda lacking for me, there's nine stages / bosses, there's a secret boss in most stages, but it's usually one of the other bosses showing up to complicate the fight. Which is all fine and good, I would just like more. Rat King, Rahzar, Chrome Dome, War,  maybe some Shredder variants like Cyber Shredder. I want more bosses to fight, cause the game is fun.

Charms - Regarding the charm system, it is a little frustrating at times. Kid of like Monster Hunter Tri. The charms you get drop from either items or strong enemies, but you can't really reliable fix them. You just get randomly placed skills. It'd be nice if the charm system worked in a way that you could fuse charms together to sort of customize your own charm. Say, you have a level 3 charm, it'd be nice to be able to fuse 3 other level 3 charms in to that one that have strength up or summat on it, to be able to place the strength up on to the host charm.

TL;DR - All in all, the game is fine. Maybe not worth $60 in its current state, but no where near as bad as people make it sound. Don't let the negative reviews stop you from playing it if you want to. Keep an eye out for a nice sale, try to get some buddies, and rock it up. So far, I don't regret buying it at full price. I've had a lot of good times playing with friends.

MKutants in Manhattan isn't a bad game.  you want a score out of 10 its a 6, a score out of 5 its a 3. It's not a bad game I honestly believe that, even if my card carrying TMNT fan club would suggest some biased. It just never lives up to the potential seen in it, and ultimetly, that potential makes it's failures all the worse.
As a license game, the turtles have faired alot better then other franchises in transition from page to screen to controller. Back in the hands of Konami in the 80's to mid 2000's they had a string of succesful brawlers and puzzel games. But as the games moved over to Ubisoft with the 2007 film, and more recently Activision, the results have been more stale.
So the latest installment starts out as a breath of fresh air, An updated brawler, in some open enviroments, you can run around and light attack heavy attack your enemies, and come across missions to protect the city. There's a decent supply in Enemy variation, with your standard soldiers, bomb throwers, grapplers and pro's offering at least some variety in attacks. Missions vary from protections, defeact all the enemies, stealth attacks and retrieve the item, Not alot of variety, but plenty of games have less. Complete enough of these, you'll find the location of the boss, and you do battle, where you'll need to make heavy use of your Ninjitsu skills and backing up the other turtles to clean out the health bars.
The game play feels good, especially if you can get use to the block/dodge system. But there are times when instead of throwing some tougher enemies at you, the just throw dozens of enemies, crowding the screen and littering the enviroment with area attacks, and it soon makes the game a chore.
The Story and Character designs are influecned by the current IDW comic series, and it feels like elements have been taken not just from that, but inspiration from the current Nickelodeon tv series as well. The story is disposable unfortunatly, merely a way to frame the next fight, or explain why you are where you are. The voice acting is a mixed bag, With Raphiel sounding particuarly horrible.

Like i said, it's not a bad game, it's not a great game that you might hope for, it's slightly better then mediocre. It's not terribly long, but it probably could have been better if it were a little shorter, with a little more polish put into its enciroments and combat, and maybe a little cheaper. If you see it on sale, it's could be a steal, but at full price, it's a dissapointment. A Dissapointment i'm going to go back to.

reviewText:
Right off the bat I will say TMNT:mutants in Manhattan is much much better than Tmnt: Out of the Shadows (game) was. Platinum Games put some work into the game and it does show. Is it perfect? No. Is it fun? Very much so.

PROS
-Visual aesthetics akin to that of the comic books and are well represented here
-Lot's of things to collect.
-Light RPG aspects to the game to equip your tutrle with loadouts and special moves to which you can upgrade.
-Boss battles are engaging*
-Co-op play
-Not too long ( logged in 5 hours on normal gameplay first playthrough) but also long enough for replayability
-different difficulties offer different things ( hardest difficulty changes up some boss fights)


CONS
-Your A.I teamates: While they can be good MOST of the time, sometimes just doesn't know what to do with itself and kind of makes some bonehead descisions, like running off to fight enemies when your downed, or run into an object and rub up against it instead of getting on said thing, or while fighting a boss not use any of their specials. Overall it is fine, but once in a while, some of the A.I choices will get to you.

-30FPS lock: Now for me myself it doesn't bother me, but to some this can be an issue. Does it make the game unplayable? Not in the slightest, game still runs at a farely good rate. No slow downs during heavy combat,

-*Boss Battles: While they are engaging, they are also just extremely punishing as well. If your A.I or teamates arn't co-ordinated to dodge everything perfectly all the time ( they won't be) you will likely die, a lot. Mostly due to how unforgiving the boss fights can be with their speed and attacks which are stronger than you by a WIDE margin. There really is no point to get that 4th pizza health upgrade when the boss can one shot you with his attacks already, and this is on normal!

General Opinion
-Combat. While I find it fine, very simular to the beat em ups that konami made back when they had the license, I feel like they could have had a bit more depth to the combos. It's simple and works well for the game but it's no Bayonetta type combat that platinum is capable of doing. Which really shows during boss fights how a bit more complexity could work.

Overall however it DOESN'T make the game less fun but would have been nice to add some kind of combat combo system per turtle and not just the co-op turtle combos.

-Lack of extra stuffs: Would have been nice to unlock an arcade mode version of the game and maybe the ability to unlock some costumes instead of them just being DLC, but thats a minor thing to me.


Overall, dispite its shortcomings, this is the best TMNT game we have seen in a long while. Hopefully Platinum can make another one and improve on some of the things that need to be addressed.  7.5/10

I started playing this around noon today, and only now finished it, completeing the normal mode, and almost finishing hard mode. It reminds me a lot of the previous Platinum games Transformers title.
This game reminds me why I love TMNT, and why I enjoy the IDW version of the comics.
after about three hours of streaming, one friend decided to buy it and join me.
That's when the fun really started. I enjoyed it alone, but with a friend, it's a blast.
I was expecting something similar to Turtles in time, but this wasn't quite there. but in a good, surprising way.

Pros:
The music was pretty catchy and amusing.
They tried to capture the humor that we know from TMNT and succeeded more often than not.
Familiar faces look great with a fresh coat of paint.
Tense boss fights.
A great mix of semi-randomly generated mission modes add a little variety and replay value.
A good 4 player co-op experience with just enough gameplay to be beaten in a single afternoon, arcade style.
Stylish, customizable combat system adds personal touches and preferences without making any one character overpowered.

Cons:
The Ai is ruthless in the sense that if you start on normal mode, it's a walk in the park until about three missions in, then you'll feel like you're doing no damage whatsoever.
If you play alone, prepare to have your partner AI pop it's attacks and skills at the worst moments.
You get to see characters like Armaggon and a nod to Rat King. but no Baxter, Casey, Mutagen Man, Mondo, Metal Head, Chrome Dome or other series staples.
The story is short with about the same number of levels as an SNES cart.
No Local Co-op was a huge dealbreaker.

All in all, I enjoyed myself, and I'll be playing more of this in the near future. the combat takes some getting used to, but the over the top art style and ranking system made the game more enjoyable for me and my friends to compete and try to outperform each other. it's a fair price for 40 usd. but unless you're a diehard turtles fan who loves beat-em-ups. you might want to wait and see if this goes on sale during the steam summer sale later in June.

This is an excellent beat-em-up hack-n-slash game, the gameplay is very fun and satisfying.  I highly recommend th is game, especially those who like ninja turtles.

*note*  The game is currently 30fps locked.  Even though in an interview the devs said the game was going to be 60fps.  I'm hoping this issue will be remedied soon.  BUT the game is still very much playable and enjoyable at 30 fps.

The fighting mechanics are solid and fluid for the most part, you have your typical light attack, heavy attack, special moves,  and dodge.  You can play one of the 4 turtles.  In singleplayer you can switch turtles on the fly, but in multiplayer you are locked into one.  Each one has their own unique set of attacks.  Special attacks can be purchased with points and upgraded to reduce their cooldowns.

The stages consist of random missions where you disarm bombs, find an item, move item from point A to B, and defend.  Then after doing a few missions you fight a boss.  The boss fights are farily challenging, for the most part they are just punching bags, but as their health gets lower they start going into a rage and deal more damage and do more attacks.  So just mashing the attack button won't help, you have to actively dodge attacks.

The online multiplayer is good, I had no lag at all, although there were pauses of waiting for player" due to connection not being good which did get annoying after a bit.

Don't let the 30 fps lock fool you. What you have here is one of the best TMNT games since Turtles in Time.

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles™: Mutants in Manhattan takes players into a cel-shaded TMNT world.  The story is an original story penned by IDW Comic’s TMNT author, Tom Waltz. What's that mean? It means it's canon.

The game stays true to the source material and all the turtles feel like their personalities are where they're supposed to be. Plus there's no Boo-ya Ka-shaws.

The combat controls work splendedly, even with a mouse and keyboard. Animations are fluid and team combination attacks feel awesome when they're pulled off. The voice acting, the music, everything is pretty much spot on. All that and more caught me completely off-guard as I expected nothing from another TMNT game. I expected I'd refund this game after playing it for an hour but I can't wait to dive in some more.

Players can level up, gain new skills, customize said skills and create a spec that matches their playing style. This also means that you'll be replaying the game over and over again to progress your character, but don't worry. The big bosses at Platinum know what's up. Stages up until the boss fight have several different events that are randomly presented to the player. What this means that each play through you do will be a different experience every time.

Nostalgia-goggles aside this is a solid game and a must buy for any action game or RPG game fan alike.

Contrary to what people are saying about the Framerate. It doesn't bother me, usually I'm all gung-ho about wanting unlocked framerates and whatnot. But it's more than tolerable here. Also I have experienced zero performance issues.

As far as the gameplay goes, I'm one of the fortunate people that has multiple friends with gaming PCs. So they are all able to run it and play along side me. The whole Couch Co-op argument is garbage in my mind, the camera just couldn't support that with how everyone runs around freely. They would have to lock it to a main area, which wouldn't be nearly as enjoyable.

The game is short, as expected coming away from Transformers: Devastation. However, it's a hack-and-slash, beat em' up type of game, so the replayabilty is based on how much you enjoy the combat and want to play higher difficulties. In my case, it's very high. I'm almost done with a Normal run through with my friends, and we will progress to higher difficulties after that.

The storyline obviously isn't great, but the way I saw this game was like a trip to the arcade to play the TMNT sidescroller. I totally get that vibe here just mashing and bashing the ever living hell out of the enemies.

Customization options are fairly solid for what it's worth. Me and my friends all play different styles, which the game allows for with the customization. Case in point, I play as the group's medic.

Overall, if you have 3 other friends who want to smash some baddies as the classic Turtles. I'd recommend this game, maybe not at $40. But your milage may vary.

reviewText:
Fantastic Game!  It really captures the Classic 90's Turtles feel.  Voice acting is on point and the humor is classic Turtles.

If you're a Turtles in Time fan like me, you'll enjoy this game.  It really feels like an old school beat'm up but with an in-depth modern combat system.  It also has quite a few enemy throwbacks to the old school arcade game, like shoulder charging Rock dudes and Bolas slinging Foot ninjas!

The stages are fairly well designed and diverse, ranging from more open exploration stages to linear progressive stages.  There is also a random objective system before you reach the stages's Boss Phase, so each playthrough is a little different.

The game has a pretty straitforward leveling system that allows you to customize your Turtles skills and abilities.  Simple, intuitive, and gives the game some variety so you can mix up your playsyle.

One of my favorite parts about this game is that it is Co-op centric.  The way you can synergize with the other players is well designed and makes it a lot of fun to coordinate with your friends online.  The single player in the game if fun, but you really won't get the full experience unless you play co-op.  Also if you play on the harder difficulties the bosses become significantly more difficult and the bots won't be able to keep up as well; and if the Secret boss appears, forget about it.  So you really want to team up with some other players.

A must play for Turtle fans.
